SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: At 4pm Sunday, May 31 2015 the NSA may End
well partially end that is...... it would end collecting bulk phone records, roving wiretaps, and other abuses of privacy and authority....
<b>Rollback of U.S. spy powers would mark post-9/11 watershed<b>

"At 3:59 p.m. EDT on Sunday, the National Security Agency and telecommunications companies will begin mothballing a once-secret system that collected Americans' bulk telephone records, shutting down computers and sealing off warehouses of digital data.

If the U.S. Congress fails to act, key provisions of the USA Patriot Act will lapse in a watershed moment in the post-Sept. 11, 2001, era. Intrusive government powers, created and wielded in the name of preventing another mass-casualty terrorist attack, would be at least partly scaled back, proponents and critics of the surveillance say."
I expect a LARGE (false flag?) terrorist attack shortly after it ends which will likely "bring it back" if it does end.......

It's not just about catching Islamic fundamentalist insurgents. It's about creating a searchable database of personal behavior. It's about being able to predict how people will respond to things happening to them in real time. It's about profiling people digitally. Everyone's physical movements, phone conversations, texts, emails, web searches, purchases, status updates etc filtered through algorithms in order to predict what they may do in the future. Even if they can't filler and efficiently use all the data they collect in these ways now they will eventually be able to.
TPTB would never give up such a thing. No matter what the talking heads say.

Good. This is one more treasure trove of information that politicians and special interests can't profit from or use against us. I have nothing to hide or no problem watching the bad guys. But after 6 years of Obamalies, government incompetence and corruption, the IRS targeting conservatives, and the DOJ waging war on police for pseudo-racism, I am ready to pull the plug on all government activities. I no longer buy the phrase "we are from the government and are here to help."
